title: 107_hr489
content: The Act titled "Math and Science Teacher Recruitment Act of 2001" revises teacher loan forgiveness programs by expanding loan forgiveness for teachers. The "Math and Science Teacher Recruitment Act of 2001" aims to expand loan forgiveness eligibility for teachers of mathematics and science in middle and secondary schools, providing incentives for them to enter and remain in the teaching profession. The program authorizes the Secretary to repay qualified loan amounts for full-time teachers in grades 7 through 12 who teach mathematics or science. To be eligible for loan forgiveness under the "Math and Science Teacher Recruitment Act of 2001," teachers must have taught mathematics or science in grades 7 through 12 for at least 3 consecutive years, have a relevant academic major or graduate degree, hold state certification or license, and not be in default on any loans. The Secretary will establish a formula for selecting borrowers for loan repayment under the "Math and Science Teacher Recruitment Act of 2001" to ensure fairness. The Secretary can repay up to $2,500 per school year for teaching math or science, or a total of $10,000. Loans used to repay Federal Direct Stafford loans may qualify for repayment. The Secretary can repay loans used to repay Federal Direct Stafford loans, Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford loans, or loans made under specific sections for eligible borrowers. Regulations may be issued by the Secretary for implementation. The section does not authorize any refunding of loan repayments. Additional eligibility provisions are in place for teachers who continue to meet requirements during service in a qualifying school. The subsection outlines eligibility for loan forgiveness for teachers in qualifying schools, with a provision to prevent double benefits. The term 'year' is defined for teacher service, and appropriations are authorized for implementation. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include new provisions for Direct Student Loans for fiscal year 2002 and the following 5 years. "Expanded loan forgiveness for teachers under SEC. 460A." The purpose of this section is to expand eligibility for loan forgiveness for teachers of mathematics and science in middle and secondary schools. The Secretary is authorized to cancel the obligation to repay qualified loan amounts for full-time teachers in grades 7 through 12 who teach mathematics or science. To be eligible for loan forgiveness, a teacher must have taught mathematics or science in grades 7 through 12 for at least 3 consecutive years, have a relevant academic major or graduate degree, hold state certification or license, and not be in default on any loans. The Secretary will establish a formula for selecting borrowers for loan repayment based on available funds. The maximum loan forgiveness amount is $10,000 or $2,500 per school year of teaching math or science in grades 7-12. Federal Direct Consolidation Loans may qualify for loan forgiveness under certain conditions. The Secretary can issue regulations to implement the loan repayment provisions. The section does not allow for loan repayment refunds. Teachers must meet specific requirements to remain eligible for loan forgiveness. The subsection outlines requirements for teachers to be eligible for loan forgiveness. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from multiple sources for the same service. The term 'year' is defined for teacher service, and appropriations are authorized for implementation.
